I'm looking at computer hardware again :ptv-hearts:
My power supply came yesterday, and I'm tired of waiting for 3 specific video cards to be for sale -_-
Right now I'm comparing one specific video card in 2070 and 2080 super formats
34.5% price increase for the latter, but performance is anywhere from 6 - 20% higher (so far), mostly around the 8-9% range, though
The, uh, super cards really dragged down the argument for choosing a 2080 over a 2070 ._.
What are your standards for game performance? 1440p @60fps or higher?
Yup, and I plan to hold onto my card for as long as possible :P
Meaning I'll probably stick with it while game settings are at least 2 or 3 notches of max settings while maintaining 60fps
from*
Cool. Do you typically play the latest games?
I'm planning to.  I've been wanting to switch to PC gaming for a while now :P
I do rather enjoy Apex Legends (even if I hated it at first)
My current ambition is to play Halo Infinite when it comes out.
I'm looking at WCCFTech's review for the Windforce cards from Gigabyte
raffle at this store had to ask if I‚Äôm 18
do I need a sign
The 2070 super is suuuuuuuper cool at 54C under gaming load and stock settings.  Bumps up to 56 with their OC
I don't know
Do you have grey hair yet? xD
I‚Äôm near 23 and people take me for 12
Oh, this is your first time looking into PC gaming? I thought you already play PC games but needed an upgrade.
For the most part I've played Blizzard titles
Those aren't exactly the most demanding
Gotcha. How long have you been researching and what persuaded you to go PC gaming?
Convenience probably? lol
I already sit on my ass in front of a computer most of the day, might as well game here instead of moving to play from a console ;)
Also, I do like mouse and keyboard for FPS games, and some less than stellar framerates on console games don't help either
Ever play the original Dark Souls on console?
No although I do have the game on my PC just waiting to be played.
There are sections of the game where it CHUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUGS
Dark Souls was originally capped at 30 fps.  That was changed with the Scholar of the First Sin edition of Dark Souls 2 where they finally upped the cap to 60
The original PC port of that game wasn't great either but it did had performance mods (DSfix) that fixed the problems.
I did not know consoles had that problem. I thought that was a Demon Souls problem with the fluctuating frame rate.
It's one of the inherent dangers of consoles.  Days Gone is another good example
No, Microsoft had some problems keeping consistent framerates in Halo 5 and in the MCC.
It was designed with the PS4 Pro in mind, and so when it first launched, PS4 owners experienced issues with framerates during huge mob sequences
PC is nicer in that you can pick and choose what settings get sacrificed for performance
Also, I'll just leave this here: https://wccftech.com/review/gigabyte-geforce-rtx-2080-super-gaming-oc-graphics-card-review/9/
ASUS apparently does have a god-tier air cooler
Them thermals
I used to play console and have a PC machine now for many reasons. Both gaming and outside of gaming.
It's worth mentioning that my 1440p monitor is also a 144hz beast ;)
So it needs...
THE POWUUUUUUUUUUUUUH
I need to experience higher than 60fps gameplay. I do not have a >120hz monitor.
I do not plan on upgrading my PC until the new consoles come out.
There is diminishing returns, but the experience will be more fluid
Personally, I can see a difference.  WoW is actually a good playground to test whether or not you can tell a difference between 60 vs 120 vs 240 fps
Oh I know. It was not a long time ago where I researched everything I could possibly know about PCs.
With the right flying mount and a solid color backdrop, you can focus on the wings to see if you can identify the individual frames of the animation
Btw, the benchmarks worry me a tad
The 2070 super from Gigabyte is setting nice and cool in the mid 50's (OC or not)
But the 2080 super sits in the mid 60's, and then shoots up to the mid 70's with an OC D:
70C on a video card is perfectly okay.
I know, it's the fact that lower temperatures also equates to longevity
Yeah but it is not like 70C is going to kill the card in a few years. That's better than my used GTX 780, which hovers around 80C.
Yet it is still kicking.
Though I did apply new thermal paste to it.

Because back then, you needed, what, the GT 8800 from Nvidia?  And that was to run max settings at 1600x900.  And you'd only get 45 fps
That said, I think these benchmarks that have the game struggling to run 60 fps at 1080p are probably using the global illumination setting
And if you turn that off, you could easily increase your fps 50%
For reference, there's 3 ways to use real-time raytracing in games
Reflections, Shadows, Global Illumination
The last one is the most expensive to run
Must fry the computer

It's just stupidly expensive to run, because it does all the lighting calculations through raytracing
